"Jack Frost" is truly a classical family movie for our time. It's the sotry about a Dad (Michael Keaton) who gets killed in a car accident. One year later, his spirit returns in the form of a lovable  snowman. While during his lifetime, he was always busy, and just didn't  make time to be with his son, now as the snowman he makes a final attempt  to let his son know that he really loved him, and that he'll be always with  him in his heart. It's good to see that Hollywood can still produce movies  that touch the heart and that are enjoyable entertainment for the whole  family. Don't forget to keep a box of Kleenex near by.

Took a gamble on Jack Frost (1998: Michael Keaton et al) being a meaningless kiddie flick. Surprising satisfying and touching, a family film with a touch of magic and lots of humor. It also dared have one teen say that life without a dad sucked - political correctivism now demands we rubbish fatherhood in spite of the true sociology, and family life (thus marriage) in general. I guess in 1998 PCism wasn't so dominant. The dad, Jack Frost, combined his love of music with his love of family, trying to do the right thing amid some conflict of loves. Ironically he died by making the right choice, but (presumably) by the grace & humor of heaven next winter found himself in a snowman's body on his family's front lawn. Initially he only revealed himself to his son (Charlie) and sought to spend quality parent time with him to make up for lost time, even to the extent of risking his meltable body. As things warm up, he follows Charlie's scheme to keep his far from abominable snowman life going forever. As crunch time comes, Jack, believing that only his body will melt, realizes that it's time to leave his widow (Gabby) and son to their mortal lives. Only at this end does Gabby meet Jack postmortem, and comes out with "my god" or "o God". Jack could have smilingly pointed upwards at this stage, since the film, being pro-marriage, pro-family, pro-fathers, pro-postmortem, could easily have gone just a little deeper into what C S Lewis called the Deeper Magic. A good family film of fun & frolic.

This is a movie that grew up watching on VHS, and now own it on DVD, and it's always been a favorite to watch around Christmas. Michael Keaton plays Jack Frost, an up-coming musician playing in a local band. He loves playing and wants to make a living out of it for his wife,played by Kelly Preston, and his son, Charlie, played by Joseph Cross. He is very close to his first big break but, unfortunately, he is missing quality time with his family. Than, one night, while driving home in the snow for Christmas, Jack crashes his car and is killed. One year later, Jack returns in the form of a walking, talking snowman. A very heartwarming and fun family film that I highly recommend.

My comments are not really needed on a crowded field with many other reviews, but I liked "Jack Frost" very much.  The interaction between Michael Keaton and Kelly Preston is excellent in the early scenes and adds a lot to the interest of the story line.  Joseph Cross, 12 years old in 1998 when "Jack Frost" was made, is excellent as their pre teenage son trying to find himself with a great love of hockey and winter sports.  Special animation is tastefully used to support the story line.
The return of Michael Keaton's character as a snowman is humorous and to some, creepy and should be explained as pure fantasy to young children: perhaps that the boy had a dream about his (recently deceased) father.

Music is also well used to keep interest, not unlike John Williams score in "Home Alone" (1990), although the music is not by Williams.

I found "Jack Frost" funny and sad in turns, especially sad in the final scene where Frost says goodbye to his son and wife.

A year later, the son does and the father comes back as a snowman at Christmas. A warm day comes threatening "dad's" life. ... you can guess the rest.

Unfortunately I didn't see the 20% rating from Rotten Tomatoes and the 5.2/10 stars from IMBD before I watched the movie. Based on the 4.5 stars on Amazon I thought that this movie would be great. Actually, it started out pretty decently with a snow battle almost comparable to upbeat, really great movies like "The Sandlot." Next thing I know, the kids dad died in a car accident. However, that's not what made it a bad movie. Plenty of great movies feature heroes that have lost a parent. This movie, on the other hand, never recovered from the shock of the father's sudden death. It flashes forward to a year later where the kid is still depressed, facing another Christmas alone. His life stinks and he is depressed. Suddenly, he builds a snowman that magically turns into his dad. Or rather, his dead father is reincarnated as the snowman. While the idea of the kid reuniting with his deceased father and rebuilding his self confidence seems heart-warming on the surface, there is something about the emotional bond between the snowman and the kid that I just couldn't get over. It was frankly creepy and almost disturbing. After watching the movie I felt very uncomfortable for the rest of the night as I tried to find some redeeming value in the movie. This is not a movie that will bring holiday cheer, this is not a movie that will help someone deal with loss of a loved one, and this is not a movie that kids or parents would likely enjoy. I really can't recommend this movie to anyone. Do not watch this movie. If you want to watch a great Christmas movie that's free with Amazon Prime, I recommend "Arthur's Perfect Christmas."

Michael Keaton dies in a car accident and his soul is inexplicably sent into the body of a snowman. The changing of the seasons is presumed to mark the death knell of this newly reanimated Keaton, but there are cold enough places that he probably could have lived within indefinitely. A walk-in freezer, or a mountain top hideaway. But no, this movie is about Keaton having to apologize to his son for being good at his job, and apparently not loving his family enough. It's not clear whether or not any of this is true, but he must make amends within an artificial timeframe. Keaton attempts to accomplish this through various awkward snowman hijinks that will probably entertain children but will either bore parents or send their thoughts into bleak existential worry about, for instance, what it means when he begins to melt. Are those his innards? Does it hurt? Why am I thinking so hard about this dumb movie? Frosty the Snowman is a better version of a possessed snowperson and utterly lacks this straw man debate about being a better parent. Plus Frosty dies a horrible death in a greenhouse at one point. Note that Jack Frost was originally going to star George Clooney but he backed out at the last minute. This is why the puppet has the "Clooney" eyebrows. The horror movie version of Jack Frost, which came out around the same time (possibly tricking some families into renting the wrong film?) was more fun because those who made it at least acknowledged what a terrible concept it was that they were putting to film. As it stands this family-friendly version is only slightly less horrifying. A disturbing film. One star.

Jack Frost (1979) is yet another Rankin Bass gem, though not nearly as popular as their other holiday specials, (such as Rudolph or Santa Claus is Comin' to Town), but is still entertaining. Perhaps its lesser popularity has to do with the story focusing on Groundhog Day, though winter itself and Christmas are loosely intertwined into the story. This movie is about a dad named Jack Frost (Michael Keaton) who gets so caught up in trying to impress the world that he forgets about his wife, portrayed by Kelly Preston, and most importantly, his son Charlie (Joseph Cross.) Fast-forward to the next Christmas; we see that Charlie is still struggling to cope with his dad's passing. His dad had spent a lot of time trying to make lots of money for his family, which his son couldn't have cared any less about. All he wanted was his dad's time, and to feel his dad's love.

One year later, Charlie builds a snowman and starts playing the harmonica that his dad had given him and had told him was a magic harmonica. Not long after, Charlie is greeted by a walking, talking snowman. Initially, Charlie is scared of it (who has ever had a snowman talk to them), and he tries to melt the snowman. Soon, Charlie realizes that his dad, who he loves with all his heart has come back to try and make things right with him. In the end, Jack makes things right with his family, particularly his son. The few hours that Jack and Charlie spend together make up for a lot of lost time, and Charlie finally gets to feel all of his dad's love all at once. Then, on Christmas, Jack finds out that his band just got a record deal but they have to leave to go to a party so the record label can hear them play. Exactly a year later, Gaby and Charlie and still struggling from the loss of Jack. Suddenly, a few hours later, the snowman comes to life after Charlie plays the hermonica his father had given to him. Jack Frost is a delightful, touching, and magical Christmas movie for the family. It begins with a father named Jack Frost (played by the wonderful Michael Keaton). Though he has very good intentions and so much love for his family (his wife Gabby played by the lovely Kelly Preston and talented newcomer Joseph Cross plays son Charlie), the demands on his time at the onset of his musical career cause him to miss out on a lot of time with them as well as important events in his son's life. The movie doesn't make Jack out to be a bad father/husband. It's apparent in his interactions/conversations with his wife and son that he's not unaware of what he's missing, he regrets it, and he's really trying to make it better (with realistic commitments set upon him by his job-relatable to all of us). The family dynamic here is truly special as they openly discuss their issues/feelings (without it being cheesy, since the dialogue is so witty and concise). Ever supportive, the family tries to work out plans so that Jack can live out his dreams (very important too) without missing out on his family life at the same time. These early scenes produce some of the greatest laughs of the movie, in my opinion. The dialogue is clever and honest. Also, despite the fact that we know this is going to turn into a snowman movie shortly, some of these moments within the family rank up for me among the most genuine and touching that I've ever seen in a family film.

So, Jack must miss out on Christmas morning with his family so he can travel with his band to a gig in order to get signed to a record deal. Halfway there, Jack decides he's made the wrong decision and heads home to surprise his wife and son. Tragically, he meets an untimely end on the way there. Now we cut to one year later and Charlie is a changed little boy. Still a sweet young man, he's understandably filled with deep sadness and disappointment over the loss. When it hits him the hardest, he goes out to build a snowman like he did with his father the year before and then blows on a "magic harmonica" that Jack had pretended he would always be able to hear. Surprisingly enough, the magic works and Jack has a chance to spend some real quality time with his son and help him through this terrible turn of events. The result is a hilarious, snow-filled, Christmas movie with a lighthearted, but sob-worthy ending. Who would have thought? :) Very impressive!
